keywords.value: VIOLATIONS OF SECURITIES AND COMMODITIES REGULATIONS

docs.snippet: James Estrin/The New York Times Eliot Spitzer arrived in Buffalo just after 2 p.m. wearing what could be called patriotic casual: pleated white slacks, red golf shirt, and a blue blazer. After greeting supporters, he took hardest shot yet at the L...
docs.abstract: James Estrin/The New York Times Eliot Spitzer arrived in Buffalo just after 2 p.m. wearing what could be called patriotic casual: pleated white slacks, red golf shirt, and a blue blazer. After greeting supporters, he took hardest shot yet at the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation, calling the rebulding efforts at ground zero "an Enron-style debacle." [...]

docs.lead_paragraph: Larry Ingrassia, business editor, Kurt Eichenwald, investigative reporter, and Joe Nocera, business columnist, discuss the upcoming trial of Kenneth L. Lay and Jeffrey K. Skilling.

docs.snippet: Andrew S. Fastow, the former chief financial officer of Enron, and his wife, Lea, have agreed to plead guilty to crimes today in Houston, people involved in the case said.    Business Day, Page C1....
docs.lead_paragraph: Andrew S. Fastow, the former chief financial officer of Enron, and his wife, Lea, have agreed to plead guilty to crimes today in Houston, people involved in the case said. Business Day, Page C1.

docs.snippet: Plea negotiations collapsed between the government and two prominent defendants in the Enron criminal cases -- Andrew S. Fastow, the company's former chief financial officer, and his wife, Lea -- after a judge questioned the amount of prison time ...
docs.lead_paragraph: Plea negotiations collapsed between the government and two prominent defendants in the Enron criminal cases -- Andrew S. Fastow, the company's former chief financial officer, and his wife, Lea -- after a judge questioned the amount of prison time to be served by Mrs. Fastow. Business Day, Page C1.

docs.snippet: Two years after Enron, then one of America's most admired companies, was revealed as a fraud, prosecutors finally seem to be getting somewhere. Andrew Fastow, the company's former chief financial officer, and his wife, Lea, are reported to be enga...
docs.lead_paragraph: Two years after Enron, then one of America's most admired companies, was revealed as a fraud, prosecutors finally seem to be getting somewhere. Andrew Fastow, the company's former chief financial officer, and his wife, Lea, are reported to be engaged in plea-bargaining. Mr. Fastow's testimony will probably lead to charges against other former Enron executives. But it would be a big mistake to conclude that the system is working. It isn't.
docs.abstract: Paul Krugman Op-Ed column says despite news of plea-bargaining by top official of bankrupt Enron Corp, the system is still broken; says wave of scandals at Enron and many other corporations was made possible, if not caused, by political climate in which corporate insiders got whatever they wanted; says politicians who did their bidding have not paid any price, so climate has not changed; cites effort to make companies count issue of stock options as cost; says when Financial Accounting Standards Board tried to issue that rule in 1994, companies that issue many options mounted lobbying campaign and Sen Joseph Lieberman's resolution opposing change was approved, 88 to 9; says board backed down; says options were big motivator for corporate fraud, but Congress has still not moved to require that issuing them be counted against profits; notes Democratic presidential contenders Wesley Clark and Howard Dean have promised to crack down on corporate tax shelters (M)

docs.snippet: LEAD: The Enron Corporation, a natural gas pipeline company, said that an arbitration panel had determined that American International Group, a private New York-based insurance company, and various other insurors were liable for $162 million in a ...
docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: The Enron Corporation, a natural gas pipeline company, said that an arbitration panel had determined that American International Group, a private New York-based insurance company, and various other insurors were liable for $162 million in a two-year-long, $200 million policy dispute. American International led the group of companies that insured Belco Inc., Enron's wholly owned

byline.original: Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: A former executive of the Enron Corporation's defunct high-speed Internet unit pleaded guilty Tuesday to one count of conspiracy related to the company's financial collapse.    The executive, Kevin P. Hannon, 44, formerly chief operating officer o...
docs.lead_paragraph: A former executive of the Enron Corporation's defunct high-speed Internet unit pleaded guilty Tuesday to one count of conspiracy related to the company's financial collapse. The executive, Kevin P. Hannon, 44, formerly chief operating officer of Enron Broadband Services, was ordered to yield $2.2 million in assets and $8 million in deferred compensation from Enron's bankruptcy estate to the Justice Department and $1 million to the Securities and Exchange Commission.
docs.abstract: Kevin P Hannon, former chief operating officer of Enron Broadband Services, pleads guilty to one count of conspiracy related to company's financial collapse; is ordered to yield $2.2 million in assets and $8 million in deferred compensation from Enron's bankruptcy estate to Justice Department and $1 million to Securities and Exchange Commission (S)

docs.snippet: The Securities and Exchange Commission and Wall Street's system of informally policing big corporations failed in their duty to detect the impending accounting failure at Enron, a Senate panel says in a report being released Monday.     The report...
docs.lead_paragraph: The Securities and Exchange Commission and Wall Street's system of informally policing big corporations failed in their duty to detect the impending accounting failure at Enron, a Senate panel says in a report being released Monday. The report, from the Senate Governmental Affairs Committee, says the oversight system must be tighter.
docs.abstract: Senate Governmental Affairs Committee report says Securities and Exchange Commission and Wall Street's system of informally policing big corporations failed in their duty to detect impending accounting failure at Enron Corp (S)

docs.snippet: The Enron Corporation said today that it had agreed to call off the sale of Portland General Electric, a $1.8 billion deal that was reached just weeks before the company collapsed in bankruptcy last December.     Enron had planned to sell P.G.E., ...
docs.lead_paragraph: The Enron Corporation said today that it had agreed to call off the sale of Portland General Electric, a $1.8 billion deal that was reached just weeks before the company collapsed in bankruptcy last December. Enron had planned to sell P.G.E., the largest and oldest utility in Oregon, to the Northwest Natural Gas Company, which has its headquarters a few blocks from P.G.E. in downtown Portland.
docs.abstract: Enron Corp agrees to call off sale of Portland General Electric, $1.8 billion deal that was reached just weeks before company collapsed in bankruptcy last December; Enron planned to sell company to Northwest Natural Gas Co (S)
